tweets.text: He‚Äôs trying to unlock other ways of thinking by shifting our perspective. And whips up amazing demos üòé
We should have something better than code. I have no idea what that will be, but I‚Äôm fascinated by Bret Victor‚Äôs research.

My clarity of thinking improved massively once programming clicked.

But gaining that through code is not for most people.
Code is terrible for most people. It‚Äôs a horrible interface to gaining intuitive rationality.

I think much of that movement is a ruse from on high.

All they talk about is the dollars they can gain. https://t.co/2TntgyyySR

tweets.text: Oh, I‚Äôd also add don‚Äôt try to win anything by it. I‚Äôm not aiming for core team or anything. The work is worthy in and of itself üòÅ
If you want to contribute to Rails, I‚Äôd say thoughtful feedback focusing on tuning PR readability is your best bet. Keep building trust!
Kept reviewing pull requests and made it to Rails‚Äô committers team June-July.
Because of my long history with the Rails people (they knew to trust me), I was promoted to Rails‚Äô issues team.
Early 2015, I started watching the Rails repo, just to get a feel for things. About 2-3 weeks in, I began reviewing PRs.
Then things went pretty quiet until I started helping out with Rails‚Äô Global ID repo mostly in August-October 2014.
Never did anything of note until I was a Google summer of code student for Rails. https://t.co/WM1fQVFa4c
